%text \textbf{Second Fundamental Theorem} We are listing this first because this is the formula you will use most often.
If $f(x)$ be a \underline\text{continuous function} \underline\text{in [a,b]} and there be a $F(x)$ such that $\dfrac{d}{dx}F(x) = f(x)$, then
\[ \quad \int_a^b f(x)\cdot dx = \left[ F(x) \right]_a^b = F(b) - F(a) \]
\textbf{Basic Properties}
% \begin{align} \int_a^b f(x)\cdot dx &= -\int_b^a f(x)\cdot dx \\ \int_a^a f(x)\cdot dx &= 0 \\ \int_a^c f(x)\cdot dx &= \int_a^c f(x)\cdot dx + \int_c^b f(x)\cdot dx \end{align}
%text
\textbf{First Fundamental Theorem} Let the function $A(x)$ be defined as \[ \qquad A(x) = \int_a^x f(x)\cdot dx \]
Basically, $A(x)$ is the \underline\text{area under $f(x)$} from $a\longrightarrow x$.
Given this, the first fundamental theorem says that \[ \dfrac{d}{dx} A(x) = f(x) \]
In other words, as one goes from $x\rightarrow (x+\Delta)$, the area -- $A(x)$ -- under the curve \underline\text{increases at the rate of $f(x)}
